awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of a QUATTRO II Mass Spectrometer for the W.M.  Keck Resource Laboratory at Yale University
awd_abstract_narration: Over the past few years there has been tremendous  advances in the sensitivity of mass spectrometers for  peptide sequencing, the ability of parent ion scanning  approaches to rapidly detect and identify a plethora of  protein posttranslational modifications and the promise of  gentle ionization techniques to extend mass spectroscopy  into the realm of non-covalent protein interactions and  folding. These techniques have been disseminated slowly  because of the small number of laboratories with  demonstrated track record in these new techniques. The  current proposal is intended to bring state-of-the-art mass  spectroscopy to Yale University through the purchase of a  QTOF mass spectrometer. This instrument will support  research in 10 institutions that do not currently have a  comparable instrument. The projects include a broad spectrum  of biological research areas including tRNA synthesis; pre-  mRNA maturation; early neurogenesis; the control of cellular  differentiation and growth; intracellular membrane  transport; protein structure and dynamics; the generation of  antigen receptor diversity; and the role of cell surface  glycosylation in establishing cellular identity.
